titleStmt.title: WASP-189b: an ultra-hot Jupiter transiting the bright A star HR 5599 in a polar orbit ⋆

affiliation.orgName: Space sciences, Technologies and Astrophysics Research (STAR) Institute

analytic.title: WASP-189b: an ultra-hot Jupiter transiting the bright A star HR 5599 in a polar orbit ⋆

biblStruct.note: Accepted XXX. Received YYY; in original form 2018 September 13
MNRAS 000, 1-10 (2018) Preprint 14 September 2018 Compiled using MNRAS L A T E X style file v3.0

textClass.keywords: planets and satellites: detection -planets and satellites: individual: WASP-189b -stars: individual: WASP-189 -stars: individual: HR 5599

abstract.p: We report the discovery of WASP-189b: an ultra-hot Jupiter in a 2.72-d transiting orbit around the V = 6.6 A star WASP-189 (HR 5599). We detected periodic dim-mings in the star's lightcurve, first with the WASP-South survey facility then with the TRAPPIST-South telescope. We confirmed that a planet is the cause of those dim-mings via line-profile tomography and radial-velocity measurements using the HARPS and CORALIE spectrographs. Those reveal WASP-189b to be an ultra-hot Jupiter (M P = 2.13 ± 0.28 M Jup ; R P = 1.374 ± 0.082 R Jup) in a polar orbit (λ = 89.3 ± 1.4 • ; Ψ = 90.0 ± 5.8 •) around a rapidly rotating A6IV-V star (T eff = 8000 ± 100 K; v * sin i * ≈ 100 km s −1). We calculate a predicted equilibrium temperature of T eql = 2641 ± 34 K, assuming zero albedo and efficient redistribution, which is the third hottest for the known exoplanets. WASP-189 is the brightest known host of a transiting hot Jupiter and the third-brightest known host of any transiting exoplanet. We note that of the eight hot-Jupiter systems with T eff > 7000 K, seven have strongly misaligned orbits, and two of the three systems with T eff ≥ 8000 K have polar orbits (the third is aligned).

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: With ∼750 transiting planets well studied the emphasis is on pushing planet discovery into regimes where there are few known planets. Of the 580 host stars listed in the TEPCat database (Southworth 2011), only 9 have stellar effec-⋆ Based on observations collected at the European Organisation for Astronomical Research in the Southern Hemisphere under ESO programme 0100.C-0847.

† E-mail: d.r.anderson@keele.ac.uk tive temperature T eff > 7000 K. This is because the spectral lines of very hot, rapidly rotating stars are sparse and broad, which complicates the radial-velocity verification of planets. Hence we know little about the formation and evolution of planets around hot stars.

Under the core accretion model of planet formation, giant planets are expected to be more common around more massive stars ( Pollack et al. 1996), with an occurrence rate predicted by Kennedy & Kenyon (2008) to increase linearly with stellar mass over the range 0.4-3 M ⊙ . Indeed, Cumming et al. (2008) found that the occurrence rate of gi-ant planets (planet mass M P = 0.3-10 M Jup ; orbital period P = 2-2000 d) is ten times lower for M dwarfs (1 per cent) than for FGK stars (10.5 per cent). Whether this trend continues to A stars is unknown. Borgniet et al. (2017) reported an occurrence rate of 4 +10 −4
per cent for A-type stars (M P = 0.1-10 M Jup ; P = 1-1000 d), which is too imprecise to tell.

An additional motivation to discover planets around hot stars is their potential for characterisation. As hot stars are intrinsically luminous, many bright stars (which are easier to study) are hot stars: of the Bright Star Catalogue (Hoffleit & Jaschek 1991), 41 per cent are listed as OBA stars and 21 per cent are listed as A stars. Also, planets in close orbits around hot stars are intensely irradiated, which facilitates the probing of their atmospheres. For example, a great deal of work has been done to characterise the atmosphere of WASP-33b ; T eff = 7430 K; V = 8.2; P = 1.22 d) from detections of its thermal emission ( Smith et al. 2011;Deming et al. 2012;de Mooij et al. 2013;Haynes et al. 2015;von Essen et al. 2015;Nugroho et al. 2017;Zhang et al. 2018).

In their initial configuration the WASP survey facilities operated with 200-mm f/1.8 lenses, as described by Pollacco et al. (2006), targetting stars in the range V = 9-13. WASP-South ran in this mode from 2006 to 2012, resulting in the discovery of 125 planets (some jointly with SuperWASP-North). But WASP-South saturated at V = 9, and the brightest planet-host found in the South was WASP-18 at V = 9.3 (Hellier et al. 2009). Since several brighter hosts were known in the North we decided to switch to Canon 85-mm f/1.2 lenses, with an SDSS r-band filter and shorter exposures (three 20-s exposures per pointing instead of two 30-s exposures), so covering the range V = 6.5-11. WASP-South ran in this configuration from 2012 to 2015.

This survey mode is similar to that of the KELT project ( Pepper et al. 2007), which uses a Mamiya 80-mm f/1.9 lens, and which has been vindicated by spectacular discoveries such as KELT-9 ( Gaudi et al. 2017) and KELT-20/MASCARA-2 ( Lund et al. 2017;Talens et al. 2018), which are both V = 7.6 systems. KELT-9b, which transits the hottest known hot-Jupiter host (T eff ≈ 10 200 K), is already proving invaluable for atmospheric characterisation ( Hoeijmakers et al. 2018).
In this paper we present the discovery of WASP-189b, an ultra-hot Jupiter transiting an even brighter star, being in a polar orbit around the mid-A star WASP-189 (HR 5599; V = 6.6; T eff = 8000 K).

div.head: PHOTOMETRIC AND SPECTROSCOPIC OBSERVATIONS
div.p: We present in Table 1 a summary of our photometric and spectroscopic observations of WASP-189. We observed WASP-189 during 2012 Jul to 2013 Aug with the modified WASP-South survey facility. Our search techniques are described in Collier Cameron et al. (2006Cameron et al. ( , 2007. We detected a dip of a few mmag and with a periodicity of 2.72 d in the WASP-South lightcurve (Fig. 1 Figure 1. WASP-South survey lightcurve folded on the adopted ephemeris from Table 3 and binned (bin width equivalent to 2 min).

Using HARPS on the ESO 3.6-m telescope (Pepe et al. 2000), we obtained a series of spectra during the transit night of 2018 Mar 26. Using the HARPS Data Reduction Software (DRS), we computed average stellar line profiles, or cross-correlation functions (CCFs), by crosscorrelating the HARPS spectra with a weighted A0 binary mask from which we had removed various tellurics and ISM lines ( Baranne et al. 1996;Pepe et al. 2002). The time-series of these CCFs constitute the HARPS Doppler tomography data set, DT HAR . We discarded the last two spectra of the series as they were visibly affected by twilight. In the resulting tomogram (top-left panel of Fig. 2), there is a trace indicative of a planet in a polar orbit crossing the red-shifted hemisphere of the star. However, due to ephemeris uncertainty (our initial attempts to refine the ephemeris with additional transit photometry were unsuccessful) we had missed the ingress of the event and we were concerned about possible lunar contamination. The Moon, which was 77 per cent illuminated and at a distance of ∼95 • from the target, had set at 06:46 UT. The barycentric Earth velocity was 18.5 km s −1 . The trace in the tomogram occurs at a similar velocity and is apparent in the CCFs taken up to 06:04 UT. We cross-correlated with the A0 mask the sky spectra taken simultaneously using the secondary HARPS fibre and found no signal (Fig. 3), which indicates that the signal in the target tomogram is not due to the Moon.

Using CORALIE, we obtained a series of spectra during the transit night of 2018 Jul 13. The Moon posed no issue as it was only 2 per cent illuminated and it set at 23:01 UT (26 min before the CORALIE sequence began). We again computed CCFs using the A0 mask to produce the CORALIE Doppler tomography data set, DT COR . In the resulting tomogram (top-right panel of Fig. 2), there is a trace indicative of a planet in a polar orbit crossing the red-shifted hemisphere of the star. This is similar to the trace in the DT HARPS tomogram, which occurs at a similar barcyentric RV.

We also obtained spectra around the orbit, 5 with CORALIE and 16 with HARPS. We again computed CCFs by cross-correlating the spectra with the same A0 mask as before. We used the DRS to calculate RVs from all of the CCFs (including DT HAR and DT COR ), which it does by fitting a Gaussian, but we found the scatter about the bestfitting orbit to be large ( Fig. 4; weighted RMS = 163 m s −1 ). So we instead calculated the RVs by fitting the CCFs, which we detrended using a linear function fit to the wings, with a simple rotationally broadened profile (Gray 1976):
div.formula: contrast(v) = c 1 1 − (v − RV) RV 2 + c 2 1 − (v − RV) RV 2 + c 3 (1)
div.p: where v is velocity. The first and second terms parameterise rotation and limb-darkening, respectively, and the third term is an offset. The scatter about the best-fitting orbit was thus much reduced (bottom panel of

div.head: STELLAR PROPERTIES OF WASP-189
div.p: We co-added the individual HARPS spectra from the transit night to obtain an average signal-to-noise of ∼200:1. We estimated the stellar effective temperature, T eff = 8000 ± 100 K, from the Balmer lines, assuming a stellar surface gravity of log g * = 4.0. We estimated the projected stellar rotation speed v * sin i * = 100 ± 5 km s −1 from broadening. We find the metallicity is around Solar. These parameters are consistent with those in the literature (e.g. Kunzli et al. 1997;Royer et al. 2002;Díaz et al. 2011;David & Hillenbrand 2015). HR 5599 was claimed to be an A5m star by Cowley (1968), whilst Renson et al. (1991) listed it as an A4m star and noted its identification as a metallic-line star to be doubtful. We do not see evidence in the spectra that HR 5599 is an Am star: the Ca K line is not weak and was fit with normal abundance for the star's T eff . Houk & Swift (1999) classified the star as A4-5IV-V . We found a spectral type of A6IV-V using the mkclass spectral classification code of Gray & Corbally (2014).

We calculated the distance to WASP-189 (d = 99 ± 1 pc) using the Gaia DR2 parallax of 9.999 ± 0.075 mas ( Lindegren et al. 2018), which we corrected to 10.08 ± 0.11 mas using the systematic offset of −82 ± 33 µas suggested by Stassun & Torres (2018) to apply to bright, nearby stars. This is consistent with the Hipparcos value of 10.29 ± 0.81 mas (van Leeuwen 2007). We calculated the effective temperature (T eff,IRFM = 7980 ± 170 K) and angular diameter (θ = 0.218 ± 0.011 mas) of the star using the infrared flux method (IRFM) of Blackwell & Shallis (1977), assuming reddening of E(B − V) = 0.02 estimated from the Na D lines. We thus calculated its luminosity and its radius (log(L * /L ⊙ ) = 1.293 ± 0.045 and R * ,IRFM = 2.33 ± 0.12 R ⊙ ). We summarise the stellar properties in Table 2.

We inferred M * = 1.887 ± 0.057 M ⊙ and age τ = 0.855 ± 0.080 Gyr using the bagemass stellar evolution MCMC code of Maxted et al. (2015) with input of the values of ρ * from our adopted combined analysis (Section 4) and T eff and [Fe/H] from the spectral analysis (Fig. 6). We note that the mass and age are consistent with the values from David & Hillenbrand (2015) (M * = 1.9 ± 0.2 M ⊙ ; τ = 0.83±0.15 Gyr), and the mass is within 1 σ of the adopted value from our combined analysis (Section 4). By combining our values of M * and R * ,IRFM , we calculated log g * = 3.98 ± 0.06.

Our values of T eff and L * suggest that WASP-189 is in the instability strip and may be a δ-Scuti star. If so then it may exhibit photometric variations with amplitude of a few mmag to tenths of a mag and with a period of 18 min to 8 hr ( Aerts et al. 2010). Similarly, our values for T eff and log g * (from both Table 2 and Table 3) place WASP-189 in the region occupied by delta-Scuti stars (see the bottom panel of fig. 4 in Smalley et al. 2017). This may explain the correlated noise in our follow-up transit lightcurves (Fig. 5). We searched the WASP lightcurves for modulation using the method of Maxted et al. (2011). We found no convincing signal and place an upper limit of ∼5 mmag on the amplitude of any sinusoidal signal. Further observation is required to test whether the star is a delta Scuti, which will be done by TESS ( Ricker et al. 2015).

div.head: SYSTEM PARAMETERS FROM MCMC ANALYSIS
div.p: We determined the system parameters from a simultaneous fit to the lightcurves, the RVs, and the CCFs using the current version of the Markov-chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) code presented in Collier Cameron et al. (2007) and described further in Collier Cameron et al. (2010a) and Anderson et al. (2015). We modelled the transit lightcurves using the formulation of Mandel & Agol (2002) and limbdarkening was accounted for using the four-parameter nonlinear law of Claret (2000) (see Table 3 for the interpolated coefficients). The fitted parameters were orbital period P, transit epoch T c , transit duration T 14 , planet-to-star area ratio R 2 P /R 2 * , and impact parameter b. We parameterised the Keplerian RV orbit by T c , P, the stellar reflex velocity semiamplitude K 1 , and the systemic velocity γ (one per dataset). Table 3. The mean out-of-transit CCF (which is a CCF made up of the mean value in the out-of-transit portion of the time-series at each wavelength) has been subtracted, leaving the bright signature of the starlight blocked by the planet during transit. The stellar velocity of the planet trace appears constant, indicating a polar orbit, and the offset of the trace from the systemic velocity (on the receding limb of the star) indicates a non-zero impact parameter. The white, vertical marks indicate the positions of the systemic velocity (γ) and the limits of the stellar rotation velocity (γ ± v * sin i * ,DT ). The white, horizontal marks indicate the start and end of transit (first and fourth contact). Bottom row: The same as the top row, but after removal of the best-fitting planetary signature model. . Doppler tomogram obtained from the sky spectra observed by the secondary fibre of HARPS whilst its primary fibre was on target. Due to the absence of a similar trace in the secondary fibre tomogram, we concluded that the trace seen in the primary-fibre tomogram (Fig. 2, top-left panel) was caused by WASP-189b rather than the Moon. The range of the plot is identical to Fig. 2. The intensity scale was changed to bring out the detail, as the throughputs of the two fibres differ and no stellar profile was subtracted from the secondary fibre CCFs.
FWHM of the line-profile perturbation due to the planet v FWHM , and the systemic velocity γ DT .

Though we can measure stellar density, ρ * , directly from the transit lightcurves, we require a constraint on stellar mass M * , or radius R * , for a full characterisation of the system. For this we used our parallax-derived radius to place a Gaussian prior: R * ,IRFM = 2.33 ± 0.12 R ⊙ .

We performed three seperate MCMC analyses to obtain . Radial-velocities of WASP-189 as extracted using the DRS (green = CORALIE; blue = HARPS). We were motivated by the large scatter to improve the extraction technique. The solid line is the best-fitting orbit from an MCMC including the DRS RVs and all of the photometry. The dotted line is the best-fitting orbit to the improved RVs (Fig. 5).

seperate measurements of the stellar obliquity: the first analysis (MCMC-RM) included the transit RVs from both spectrographs, the second analysis (MCMC-DT HAR ) included the HARPS transit CCFs, and the third analysis (MCMC-DT COR ) included the CORALIE transit CCFs. As we did not fit the RM effect in the latter two analyses, we excluded the RVs taken on the transit night, except for the final four taken by HARPS and the first four taken by CORALIE (all were outside of transit). Otherwise, all RVs were included in each analysis. Table 3, binned (bin width equivalent to 10 min) and offset for display. The adopted transit model is superimposed. Vertical dashed lines indicate partitioning due to meridian flips. Bottom panel: Radial velocities from CORALIE (green) and HARPS (blue) with the adopted circular orbital model. 95 m s −1 (CORALIE transit). To account for instrumental and astrophysical offsets, we partitioned the RV datasets and fit a seperate systemic velocity to each of them.

We present in Table 3 the results of the three analyses, which are fully consistent with each other. We plot the Doppler tomograms (i.e. the residual maps of the CCF timeseries) both before and after removal of the planet model in Fig. 2, and the fit to the RM effect in Fig. 7. We plot the fits to the transit lightcurves and the RVs in Fig. 5 for our adopted solution (MCMC-DT HAR , as justified below). We see no variation in the full RV residuals (Fig. 8), as may be caused by an additional body, though the constraint is weak.

The main point to note in comparing the three solutions is that the impact parameter (and therefore related parameters) is far better constrained in the tomographic analyses than in the RM-effect analysis. The impact parameter is relatively poorly constrained by the available transit photometry, but it is well constrained by the path that the planet traces out in the CCF time-series. We adopt the MCMC-DT HAR solution due to the high S/N of the HARPS CCFs, which results in a higher precision for b and related parameters.

We find a projected stellar obliquity of λ = 89.3 ± 1.4 • (projected because the inclination of the stellar spin axis relative to the line of sight i * is unknown). Following the method of Iorio (2011), we can place limits on the true stellar obliquity Ψ by requiring the stellar rotation speed to be smaller than the break-up speed. For our adopted solution, we obtain 1-σ limits of: 11.7 • < i * < 168.3 • and Ψ = 90.0 ± 5.8 • . We can place such a tight constraint on Ψ as it depends little on i * for polar orbits. Note: a Impact parameter is the distance between the centre of the stellar disc and the transit chord: b = a cos i/R * . b Note that the orbital RV datasets were identical for MCMC-DT HAR and MCMC-DT COR , but each contained four fewer points for MCMC-RM. c T eql was calculated assuming a zero-albedo planet using
div.formula: T eql = f 1/4 T eff R * /2a
div.p: , where f parameterises the redistribution of heat. The instant re-radiation case is dealt with by Cowan & Agol (2011).

div.head: DISCUSSION
div.p: We have presented the discovery of WASP-189b, an ultrahot Jupiter (M P = 2.13 ± 0.28 M Jup ; R P = 1.374 ± 0.082 R Jup ) in a 2.72-d, polar orbit (Ψ = 90.0 ± 5.8 • ; λ = 89.3 ± The RM effect produces an apparent blue-shift that varies little between the second and third transit contacts, indicating that the planet is in a polar orbit crossing the red-shifted hemisphere of the star.

With the most confidently polar orbit (Ψ = 90.0 ± 5.8 • ) of any system, WASP-189 continues the trend that the spins of hot stars tend to be misaligned with the orbits of their hot Jupiters ( Fig. 9; Winn et al. 2010). We note that only one of the eight known systems with T eff > 7000 K is aligned (KELT-20/MASCARA-2). Of the three systems with T eff ≥ 8000 K, one is aligned and two have polar orbits (WASP-189 and KELT-9). Perhaps this is telling us something about the states that systems are driven toward by tides (Lai 2012;Rogers & Lin 2013), angular momentum transport by internal gravity waves ( Rogers et al. 2012), or a combination of the two.

figure.head: Fig. 5 ,
figure.figDesc: note the reduced range in the RV axis compared to Fig. 4; weighted RMS = 70 m s −1 ). We conducted photometric follow-up using the 0.6-m TRAPPIST-South imager (Gillon et al. 2011; Jehin et al. 2011) and a red continuum cometary narrowband filter on the transit nights of 2018 Jul 13, 2018 Jul 24 and 2018 Aug 4. We processed the resulting time-series of images to obtain lightcurves using standard differential photometry techniques. In the lightcurve from 2018 Jul 13 there is an ingress coincident with the start of the planetary signature in the CORALIE tomogram, which was taken simultane- ously (Figs. 2 and 5). When phased on our adopted transit ephemeris (Section 4), the egresses in the TRAPPIST-South lightcurves are concident with the end of the planetary sig- nature in the HARPS tomogram (Figs. 2 and 5).

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 2. Top row: Doppler tomograms (residual maps of the CCF time-series) through transits of WASP-189b from HARPS (left) and CORALIE (right), phased on the empherides of Table 3. The mean out-of-transit CCF (which is a CCF made up of the mean value in the out-of-transit portion of the time-series at each wavelength) has been subtracted, leaving the bright signature of the starlight blocked by the planet during transit. The stellar velocity of the planet trace appears constant, indicating a polar orbit, and the offset of the trace from the systemic velocity (on the receding limb of the star) indicates a non-zero impact parameter. The white, vertical marks indicate the positions of the systemic velocity (γ) and the limits of the stellar rotation velocity (γ ± v * sin i * ,DT ). The white, horizontal marks indicate the start and end of transit (first and fourth contact). Bottom row: The same as the top row, but after removal of the best-fitting planetary signature model.

figure.head: Figure 3
figure.figDesc: Figure 3. Doppler tomogram obtained from the sky spectra observed by the secondary fibre of HARPS whilst its primary fibre was on target. Due to the absence of a similar trace in the secondary fibre tomogram, we concluded that the trace seen in the primary-fibre tomogram (Fig. 2, top-left panel) was caused by WASP-189b rather than the Moon. The range of the plot is identical to Fig. 2. The intensity scale was changed to bring out the detail, as the throughputs of the two fibres differ and no stellar profile was subtracted from the secondary fibre CCFs.

figure.head: Figure 4
figure.figDesc: Figure 4. Radial-velocities of WASP-189 as extracted using the DRS (green = CORALIE; blue = HARPS). We were motivated by the large scatter to improve the extraction technique. The solid line is the best-fitting orbit from an MCMC including the DRS RVs and all of the photometry. The dotted line is the best-fitting orbit to the improved RVs (Fig. 5).

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 5. Top panel: Transit photometry from WASP-South (grey) and TRAPPIST-South (green) folded on the adopted ephemeris from Table 3, binned (bin width equivalent to 10 min) and offset for display. The adopted transit model is superimposed. Vertical dashed lines indicate partitioning due to meridian flips. Bottom panel: Radial velocities from CORALIE (green) and HARPS (blue) with the adopted circular orbital model.

figure.head: Figure 6 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 6. Modified Hertzsprung-Russell diagrams showing the results of the bagemass MCMC analysis for WASP-189 using ρ ⋆ from the combined analysis (Section 4) and T eff and [M/H] from Table 2. The grey dots are the steps in the Markov chain. The dotted line (black) is the ZAMS. The solid lines (brown) are isochrones for τ = 0.855 ± 0.080 Gyr . The dashed lines (blue) are evolutionary tracks for M * = 1.887 ± 0.057 M ⊙ . The black point with error bars are the values of T eff and ρ * measured from the spectra and the transit lightcurves, respectively.

figure.head: 1. 4 •Figure 7 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 7. The RM effect of WASP-189b revealed by RVs from CORALIE (brown) and HARPS (violet). The best-fitting orbital model has been subtracted. The best-fitting RM model is plotted. The RM effect produces an apparent blue-shift that varies little between the second and third transit contacts, indicating that the planet is in a polar orbit crossing the red-shifted hemisphere of the star.

figure.head: Figure 8 .Figure 9 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 8. The residual RVs about the best-fitting Keplerian orbital and RM effect models from the MCMC-RM analysis (CORALIE orbital RVs = green; CORALIE RM RVs = brown; HARPS orbital RVs = blue; HARPS RM RVs = violet). The data are consistent with no variation, though only the the CORALIE orbital RVs span a significant duration.

body.note: MNRAS 000, 1-10 (2018) WASP-189b: an ultra-hot Jupiter transiting HR 5599 7
There are six known hosts of non-transiting hot Jupiters brighter than WASP-189 in the range V = 4.1-6.3: ups And, tau Boo, 51 Peg, HD 217107, HD 179949 and HD 75289.

monogr.title: Our values of T eff and L * suggest that WASP-189 is in the instability strip and may be a δ-Scuti star like WASP-33
WASP-189b is set to be engulfed by its star as it ascends the giant branch: the star is predicted to expand to the planet's current orbit in ∼320 Myr

analytic.title: WASP-189 (V = 6.64) is the brightest known host of a transiting hot Jupiter by almost a magnitude. 1 The next brightest are the A stars KELT-9

monogr.title: this may result in a bright transient event

biblStruct.note: WASP-189 is the third-brightest star known to host a transiting exoplanet of any mass. The two brighter stars host multiple planets and transiting super-Earths: HD 219134 (V = 5.57

analytic.title: The transits of WASP-189b are among the shallowest detected by WASP and confirmed to be caused by an orbiting substellar body, with a transit depth (4 mmag) similar to WASP-30b
